Award.AwardTitle: R/V SIKULIAQ Oceanographic Technical Services - Year 1 of 2
Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Alaska, Fairbanks (UAF) proposes to support technical services on R/V Sikuliaq, a new, 261-foot, general purpose research vessel operated as part of the US Academic Research Fleet. The vessel is owned by NSF and operated by the University of Alaska, Fairbanks. For basic technical services, UAF will provide three shipboard technicians on each cruise on R/V Sikuliaq to support seagoing research projects and to maintain, calibrate and provide for qualified users items from their pool of shared-use research instrumentation. This is the first proposal written for technical services for this vessel. Ordinarily, the various institutions that support vessels in the Academic Fleet operate under 5-year continuing grants. In order to maintain the same proposal cycle among the various institutions, this award will be the first of a two-year continuing grant.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present report is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers,

POR.DRECONTENT:
R/V SIKULIAQ Oceanographic Technical Services - Year 1 of 2

Funding provided by this proposal provided for the following services aboard R/V Sikuliaq.

  • Provide technical support for NSF-sponsored research aboard the R/V Sikuliaq.
  • Maintain, repair, calibrate and train in the use of NSF-funded Sikuliaq shared-use equipment.
  • Assist in pre and post cruise planning with Sikuliaq scientific parties.
  • Provide shore support for NSF-funded Sikuliaq shared-use equipment.
  • Provided support for UAF representative for the Satellite Network Advisory Group (SatNAG)
  • Provide support for a web based shipboard GIS system (MapServer).

NSF researchers were provided with technical support and tools to successfully complete their scientific mission. Less than one sea day was reported lost due to science equipment maintained by funds from this proposal during the reporting period. 

Accomplishments

  • OS75 kHz Acoustic Doppler Profiler was returned to Service
  • Multi Opening and Closing Net with Environmental Sampling Systems (MOCNESS) was upgraded with new scripps software and SBE electronics
  • Rinko III Oxygen sensors were repaired and returned to service
  • All oceanographic cables were lubricated
  • .322 cable supporting CTD operations was replaced

Satellite Network Advisory Group (SatNAG)

John Haverlack is an active participant in the UNOLS Satellite Network Advisory Group (SatNAG) who's mission is to steward consistent, efficient and robust management of satellite based Internet access for the UNOLS fleet. During the 2018 calendar year John contributed significant time and effort toward the following projects:

  • · Coherent Fleetwide Cyberoam Configurations
    • o Procured and Deployed Web Application Filters to Sikuliaq Cyberoams
    • o Procured and Deployed Dual Cyberoam 50iNG devices in a High Availability configuration bringing Sikuliaq into SatNAG device compliance.
    • o Mockup shoreside network to test a re-engineered network topology which will provide a true bastion point for Internet traffic to and from the vessel.  (Ongoing Work in Progress)
  • · RVTEC 2018
    • o John lead discussion about SatNAG activities at the UNOLS RVTEC meeting.
  • · Fleet-wide Satellite Network Metric Analyzer
    • o This project (https://satnag.unols.org/metrics) provides a graphical password protected web interface to visualize fleet-wide Internet use on a per day per users granularity.
    • o This site is password protected, and not open Internet content to protect potentially sensitive information.
    • o Souce Code https://satnag.unols.org/scm/git/satnag/satnag-network-metric-analyzer

Mapserver

New server hardware was secured via this grant. The latest Debian OS (version 9) was installed onto the server.

  • Software packages (MapServer, GDAL, Postgresql, PostGIS, netcdf, gmt,
    nodejs, ...) were compiled and installed from source.
  • Bad Debian package for fonts was found and debugged
  • Debian 9 did not support all packages required by MrSiD. Packages were recompiled for Debian 9
  • Multibeam data from the Arctic was added to the data set

Outreach

R/V Sikuliaq supported STEMSEAS experience on transits from SanDiego, CA to Newport, OR and from Nome, AK to Seward, AK.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/03/2019
Modified by: Steven J Hartz
